componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Red Hat, Inc. Q4 FY 2018 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, today's call may be recorded, and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Tom McCallum, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Elise. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Red Hat's earnings call for the fourth quarter of fiscal '18. Speakers for today's call will be Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; and Eric Shander, Executive Vice President and CFO.Our earnings press re
componenttext:
Thank you, Elise. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Red Hat's earnings call for the fourth quarter of fiscal '18. Speakers for today's call will be Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; and Eric Shander, Executive Vice President and CFO.
Our earnings press release was issued today after the market closed and may be downloaded from redhat.com on the Investor Relations page. Also on this page, you'll be able to find a copy of today's prepared remarks, a schedule of currency rates and a slide deck with financial highlights and supplemental metrics that, along with our earnings release, include a reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP financial results.
During this call, we may make forward-looking statements about our future financial performance and other future events or trends, including guidance for our first quarter and full fiscal year FY '19. These statements are only predictions that may be based on what we believe today, and actual results may differ materially. These forward-looking statements are subject to the risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that could affect our financial results and the performance of our business and which we discussed in detail in our filings with the SEC, including today's press release, the risk factors and other information contained in our most recently filed Form 10-K and Form 10-Q. Red Hat assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements we may make on today's call.
And with that, let me turn the call over to Jim.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and let me add my welcome to all of you joining us on today's call. Our fourth quarter capped off an excellent year for Red Hat. Our global team executed well, and we continued to experience strong demand for our technologies that enable d
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and let me add my welcome to all of you joining us on today's call. Our fourth quarter capped off an excellent year for Red Hat. Our global team executed well, and we continued to experience strong demand for our technologies that enable digital transformation in hybrid cloud environments. We also continued to extend our strategic position as a trusted vendor for our customers as they look to modernize their data centers and adopt Red Hat technologies to build, deploy and manage cloud-native applications.
Our results were strong during the fourth quarter and contributed to several new records and milestones for the fiscal year. Here are just a few of those highlights: First, the fourth quarter marked our 64th consecutive quarter of total revenue growth; second, our annual billings proxy exceeded the $3 billion milestone, while the fourth quarter marked the first time our billings proxy exceeded $1 billion in a quarter; third, strong sales execution led to our third straight quarter of 20% or better revenue growth with 21% total revenue growth for the year. We exited Q4 with an annualized revenue run rate that exceeded the $3 billion mark; fourth, sales execution also contributed to a record total backlog of approximately $3.4 billion, up approximately 24% year-over-year; and fifth, we continued to win larger multi-year commitments from our customers. We had a record number of deals over $1 million for the fourth quarter and the fiscal year. On a year-over-year basis, we had a 50% increase in deals over $1 million in the fourth quarter and a greater than 30% increase in deals over $1 million for the year in total.
Let me discuss some more highlights regarding Q4 deals. Overall, our large deal growth for the quarter was strong due to cross-selling and solid demand. For the quarter, we closed a total of 169 deals over $1 million, and as I discussed a moment ago, that was up approximately 50% year-over-year. Within these deals, 26 were greater than $5 million, which is a record for any quarter. Included in the 26 deals were 14 that were greater than $10 million and 2 of those over $20 million. Cross-selling was strong with 81% of the top deals greater than $1 million, including 1 or more components from our group of application development related and emerging technologies offerings. 1/3 of these deals contain 5 or more technologies across our portfolio of offerings, providing evidence of the value Red Hat is delivering to our customers based on expansion of our product portfolio in recent years.
Our top industry verticals within these deals greater than $1 million were financial services, tech and media and our other category, which includes mainstream sectors such as retail, health care and manufacturing. On the technology front, our biggest announcement during the quarter was our acquisition of CoreOS, an innovator and leader in Kubernetes and container-native solitons. The acquisition of CoreOS further enhances our ability to help customers build applications and deploy them across hybrid environments.
By combining CoreOS' complementary capabilities with Red Hat's already broad Kubernetes and container-based portfolio, including OpenShift, we aim to further accelerate adoption and development of the industry's leading hybrid cloud platform for modern application workloads. CoreOS is the creator of CoreOS Tectonic, an enterprise-ready Kubernetes platform that provides automated operations, enables portability across private and public cloud providers and is based on open source software. It also offers CoreOS Quay, an enterprise-ready container registry. In addition, CoreOS' talented technical team is well known for helping to drive many of the open source innovations that are at the heart of containerized applications, including Kubernetes where it is a leading contributor. These innovations include a lightweight Linux distribution created and maintained by CoreOS called Container Linux, which automates software updates and is streamlined for running containers. We continue to believe that the next era of technology will be driven by container-based applications that span multi and hybrid cloud environments and that Kubernetes, containers and Linux will be the foundation of this transformation. Both Red Hat and CoreOS have been leaders in open source communities and in bringing Kubernetes to enterprise customers. This acquisition further enhances Red Hat as a leader of hybrid cloud and modern application deployments and will help us to expand our strategic position with customers.
In closing, we celebrated 25 years of open source software this past quarter, and Red Hat has been a major catalyst. As we welcome the team from CoreOS as part of the nearly 12,000 team of global Red Hat associates, we are excited to have them join our efforts to drive innovation and growth in the future. Let me also extend my thanks to all Red Hat associates who are keenly focused on helping our customers to succeed, and as a company, we are confident in our ability to capitalize on the market opportunity in front of us. On a final note, I hope many of you will be able to join us for the May 8 Analyst Day at Red Hat Summit in San Francisco. It will be a great opportunity to learn more about our strategic direction and innovative technologies. You'll hear directly from our customers and partners, including technology visionaries, leading industry players and cloud providers.
With that let me turn the call over to Eric.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Jim. Let me also add my appreciation for the strong execution and the efforts that our global associates delivered during the quarter and the fiscal year, which resulted in strong financial performance that was above our guidance.O
componenttext:
All right. Thank you, Jim. Let me also add my appreciation for the strong execution and the efforts that our global associates delivered during the quarter and the fiscal year, which resulted in strong financial performance that was above our guidance.
Our execution this year resulted in higher growth than FY 2017 across total revenue, non-GAAP operating income and operating cash flow and continues to be attributable to the demand for our hybrid cloud technologies. Highlighting the fourth quarter, we delivered a powerful combination of year-over-year growth of 23% for total revenue, 24% for non-GAAP operating income and 14% for operating cash flow. With that introduction, I will begin my remarks with a review of our Q4 performance, followed by a summary of the fiscal year results and then our outlook for FY '19. As I discuss our results, please note that many of the major foreign currencies that we transact business in have strengthened against the dollar since we provided guidance in December and as compared to prior year. So for this quarter, I will keep my prepared remarks focused on reported USD results with occasional references to constant currency details. You will find a more detailed table of constant currency results as well as a more detailed view of our results and reconciliations for our non-GAAP measures to GAAP in our earnings press release.
We delivered $772 million of total revenue for the fourth quarter, which was above the high end of our guidance and represented growth of 23% in USD or 18% in constant currency. We exceeded the high end of our guidance by $9 million, which included a foreign exchange tailwind of approximately $6 million. The remaining upside was driven mainly by stronger performance in our subscription business coupled with continued healthy demand for our services supporting our emerging technologies.
Subscription revenue, which is mainly renewable, constituted 88% of total revenue in Q4 and grew 22% year-over-year in USD or 18% in constant currency. High growth across our subscription portfolio drove this result. Subscription revenue for our infrastructure-related offerings was $510 million, an increase of 17% year-over-year in USD or 13% in constant currency. Subscription revenue for our application development-related and other emerging technology offerings was $173 million, an increase of 39% year-over-year in USD or 34% in constant currency. The primary driver to the performance in this area of our business was the growth we continued to experience with our Ansible, OpenShift and OpenStack technologies. The higher growth rates in these emerging technologies were partially offset by a slight moderation in the growth in our middleware offerings as some customers begin to shift their workloads from traditional physical deployments to container environments where they would run middleware as a service within the OpenShift environment. We believe these initial efforts to use middleware as a service will increase over time as customers shift more applications to container environments, benefiting our middleware results over the long run.
We view OpenShift and our middleware product as highly complementary to our overall cloud-native Application Development strategy. Application Development-related and emerging technologies revenue represented approximately 22% of total revenue, up 260 basis points from the year-ago quarter. Lastly, our services revenue of $89 million grew 29% year-over-year in USD or 23% in constant currency. The impressive growth of our services business has been fueled by the demand for consulting projects around our Ansible and OpenShift offerings.
On a non-GAAP basis, operating income of $190 million grew 24% year-over-year and non-GAAP operating margin came in at 24.6%. This quarterly result was 30 basis points higher than Q4 last year and in line with the operating margin guidance that I provided on our last call. This also includes the partial impact from the CoreOS acquisition of approximately $3 million. As a reminder, non-GAAP operating income adjusts for non-cash share-based compensation expense, amortization of intangible assets and transaction costs related to business combinations. Other income was $11 million, which included a onetime gain from the sale of a strategic investment, which we noted in our December guidance.
Shifting to taxes and EPS. Our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 18.6% for the quarter, which is inclusive of discrete tax benefits. This resulted in non-GAAP EPS of $0.91, up 46% year-over-year and $0.10 higher than our December guidance. The lower tax rate is a result of the U.S. tax reform and is the main reason for our higher non-GAAP EPS result versus our original guidance. Also related to the reform, we repatriated $486 million of foreign earnings and recorded a onetime tax expense of $123 million. The onetime tax expense was due to the transition tax on a repatriation and a remeasurement of our deferred tax assets. The onetime tax expense along with our debt discount expense of approximately $5 million are excluded from non-GAAP net income.
Turning to the balance sheet. We ended the quarter with cash and investments of approximately $2.5 billion. After factoring in the additional cash from the repatriation and the cash used for the acquisition of CoreOS, our U.S. versus non-U.S. cash-based balances represent a 58%-42% split. Our total deferred revenue at quarter end was $2.6 billion, an increase of $525 million or 25% over the same quarter a year ago.
Moving to operating cash flow. We delivered $362 million for the quarter, up 14% year-over-year. Our FX adjusted DSO was 58 days, in line with Q4 last year. Our cash flow performance was a result of higher profitability and strong billings, which was slightly moderated by our business linearity as it was weighted to the back end of the quarter. As Jim noted, we experienced significant growth in deals over $1 million, which was up 50% year-over-year. However, many of these deals closed late in the quarter. As a result, the cash will be collected in the following quarter. This monthly linearity is something that we have discussed on prior calls and continue to actively manage. The rolling 4 quarters average billings proxy was $838 million, up 21% year-over-year. As a reminder, the rolling 4 quarters billings proxy is calculated by adding revenue plus the change in deferred revenue on the cash flow statement for the last 4 quarters.
Next, let me discuss our annual backlog, which we disclose at the end of each fiscal year. Total backlog was up 24% year-over-year for our record balance in excess of $3.4 billion in USD. We define total backlog as the value of non-cancelable subscriptions and service agreements, which have billed, plus the value to be billed in the future but not yet reflected in our financial statements. The billed portion of the backlog is total deferred revenue, which was $2.6 billion. The other portion of total backlog, which has not yet billed, was in excess of $775 million, up 19% from the prior year. Of this $775 million, the portion to be billed over the next 12 months was in excess of $450 million, up approximately 36% year-over-year.
I will now review some highlights related to our bookings. We continued to drive balanced bookings growth across our major geographies. This quarter, 58% of our bookings came from the Americas, 27% from EMEA and 15% from Asia Pacific. The percent of business in the Americas was affected by a tough comparison due to the $100 million deal we closed in Q4 last year. After adjusting for this deal, the Americas would have had double-digit growth. The fourth quarter route-to-market mix was 71% from the channel and 29% from our direct sales force compared to the fourth quarter prior year's split of 69% and 31%.
Looking at our top deals, 24 out of 25 of our largest deals that were up for renewal renewed and did so in aggregate at greater than 120% of their previous value. The one deal that did not renew is with a customer that is experiencing many challenges within their industry. We continue to partner with this customer to help understand the business transformation they need to implement and where our products may help accelerate this process. On an annual basis for this metric, we renewed 99 out of 100 of the top deals at greater than 120% in aggregate. Our proxy for bookings duration was nearly 23 months, 2 months shorter than the 25 months duration reported in Q4 last year. This was, however, longer than we anticipated due to the strong growth of multi-year deals that were closed in the quarter. Looking at FY '19, we expect our billings duration metric to be 1 month lower than this past year's average of 22 months.
Now to briefly recap and summarize some of our highlights for our full fiscal year. Total revenue grew to $2.9 billion, up 21% in U.S. dollars or 20% in constant currency. Subscription revenue grew to $2.6 billion, an increase of 21% in U.S. dollars or 19% in constant currency. Subscription revenue for infrastructure-related offerings was nearly $2 billion, up 15% in U.S. dollars or 14% in constant currency. Subscription revenue for Application Development-related and other emerging technologies was $624 million, up 42% in U.S. dollars or 40% in constant currency. For FY '18, Application Development-related and other emerging technology subscriptions constituted 21% of total revenue, up from 18% last fiscal year. Non-GAAP operating income grew by 26% year-over-year. Full year operating cash flow was $923 million, up 18% for a cash flow margin of approximately 32%. We repurchased $237 million or 2.3 million shares of Red Hat stock in the fiscal year, leaving a balance of $399 million in our repurchase program.
Now I'd like to turn to guidance. Our outlook assumes current business conditions and foreign exchange rates, which have generally strengthened against the dollar year-over-year. For the full year, we are estimating total revenue guidance of $3.425 billion to $3.460 billion, up approximately 19% in USD and 17% in constant currency at the high end of the range. Given the upfront financial impact related to the recent acquisition of CoreOS, coupled with our desire to target the strong demand for container technology, we plan on maintaining a non-GAAP operating margin of 23.9% in FY '19. This plan includes more than 100 basis points of expense related to the acquisition of CoreOS. In FY '20, we anticipate increasing operating margins by 25 to 50 basis points per year while continuing to invest in the strategic growth areas. We're estimating our full year non-GAAP earnings per share to be approximately $3.38 to $3.41 per share, assuming approximately $4 million per quarter for net other income, an annual effective tax rate of 25% and approximately 185 million diluted shares.
On a GAAP basis, we expect GAAP EPS to be approximately $2.25 to $2.28 with estimated annual stock compensation expense of approximately $215 million and annual amortization expense of approximately $38 million. GAAP fully diluted EPS guidance includes non-cash interest expense related to the convertible debt discount of approximately $20 million. We estimate capital expenditures to be in a range of $55 million to $65 million. Finally, we expect our full year operating cash flow to be in a range of $1.035 billion to $1.045 billion.
We do not provide guidance on billings, but as we have experienced in past years, we expect Q1 to typically be our lowest quarter and we continue to see a modest shift to the second half of the year. Also as I mentioned previously, we are expecting a 1 month less -- 1 less month of bookings duration in FY '19. Typically, Q1 has the lowest duration of the year, but in Q1 FY '18, we closed a deal for $30 million for 3 years that both booked and billed upfront.
For Q1, we offer the following outlook: We expect revenue to be in the range of $800 million to $810 million, which is up approximately 20% in USD at the high end of the range and 16% in constant currency; we expect non-GAAP operating margin of approximately 20.5%, which includes expenses for Red Hat Summit and our regional sales kick-off events; we expect non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.68 with 185 million diluted shares; GAAP EPS is expected to be $0.42 with 187 million diluted shares. We will continue our practice of not providing quarterly cash flow guidance, but please note that it can be variable depending upon individual payments or collections.
Recapping FY '18, we delivered strong results that reflect the continued adoption of the technologies that address the opportunities around digital transformation and hybrid cloud computing. Finally, I would like to thank all of our customers who have trusted us as their business partner and our associates around the world whose dedication and hard work helped to deliver these strong results both financially and operationally for our customers. We're optimistic that the execution this year will position us well for continued future growth.
And at this point, I would like to turn the call back to Elise for our first question.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Kash Rangan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Kash Rangan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: My question had to do more with the balance sheet mechanics. When I look at the free cash flow generation of the company, which is pretty impressive, I also wanted to clarify, if you look at the growth in free cash flow from last year to this year, you've
componenttext: My question had to do more with the balance sheet mechanics. When I look at the free cash flow generation of the company, which is pretty impressive, I also wanted to clarify, if you look at the growth in free cash flow from last year to this year, you've added about $120 million, $130 million in free cash. But a lot of that growth, almost all of that growth, in fact, more of that growth comes from long-term deferred revenue increase, which we've not seen grow at this magnitude. I'm just curious to get your take on how sustainable is the dependence of the company on free cash flow growth from contract duration or more specifically, long-term deferred revenue increase. That's it for me.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I mean, I guess, Kash, as we said, I mean, obviously, we are expecting duration to go down. I mean, certainly similar to what we saw last year, we did see an uptick in the longer-term deals that we're seeing, but we feel pretty bullish about both
componenttext: Yes. So I mean, I guess, Kash, as we said, I mean, obviously, we are expecting duration to go down. I mean, certainly similar to what we saw last year, we did see an uptick in the longer-term deals that we're seeing, but we feel pretty bullish about both -- some of the short-term deals that we've got in play looking at the pipeline as well as some of the longer term. So we expect duration to come down to probably about 21 months as we look at this upcoming year from where it's at now around 22 months. But yes, we're pleased with what -- both the short-term and long-term growth on the balance sheet.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Kash, I hadn't looked at that over a multi-year time, but obviously, we guided cash flow for next year even assuming some duration pull down. So given the growth rate there, I think it's safe to assume that the growth rate really driven by changes in
componenttext: Yes. Kash, I hadn't looked at that over a multi-year time, but obviously, we guided cash flow for next year even assuming some duration pull down. So given the growth rate there, I think it's safe to assume that the growth rate really driven by changes in relative mix of short and long term.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: And I should say, I mean, the -- our previous guidance that we have given in terms of our free cash flow operating margin of between 30% and 32% is still with what we're targeting. And obviously, we're at the higher end of that as we look at next year.
componenttext: And I should say, I mean, the -- our previous guidance that we have given in terms of our free cash flow operating margin of between 30% and 32% is still with what we're targeting. And obviously, we're at the higher end of that as we look at next year.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Karl Keirstead with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Karl Keirstead with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: A question for Jim. Jim, I was intrigued by Pivotal's IPO falling on Friday. Just in the context of Red Hat placing a big bet clearly on containers, their subscription revenues, it feels like are quite a bit larger than OpenShift and their growth rate, 70
componenttext: A question for Jim. Jim, I was intrigued by Pivotal's IPO falling on Friday. Just in the context of Red Hat placing a big bet clearly on containers, their subscription revenues, it feels like are quite a bit larger than OpenShift and their growth rate, 70-plus percent. I'm just wondering if you could, just given the importance of this part of the business to the Red Hat story, just maybe briefly contrast Red Hat OpenShift with Pivotal Cloud Foundry. And maybe the answer is simply that the application path space is so strong in early stage that there's plenty of room for 2. But curious for your comments.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. Obviously, I've read it this weekend as well. I mean, we'll talk about it more at Analyst Day, and we're trying to kind of work out what we can give you instead of numbers. But just to give you a couple things, I was actually surprised at their
componenttext: Yes, yes. Obviously, I've read it this weekend as well. I mean, we'll talk about it more at Analyst Day, and we're trying to kind of work out what we can give you instead of numbers. But just to give you a couple things, I was actually surprised at their relative number of customers. We're like 650-plus customers on OpenShift. We added several hundred customers this year. I think that if you look in their filing, they added 44 net customers year-over-year. We added several hundred. We are growing faster than they are, obviously, off of a smaller base so -- but we're -- I think we're performing quite well. After reading that, I feel even better about how we're performing on OpenShift. And so we'll figure what else we can give you on that at Analyst Day, but what I'd say is we're growing faster. We have many, many, many more customers. I will also say they obviously do a top-down traditional sale, where their average customer size, if you just take their revenue and number of customers is 1.5 million. And for an emerging technology, you normally kind of have more of a bubble up, so I don't quite understand that. But overall, I would say I think OpenShift compares very favorably and gave you a couple numbers there and we'll follow up more at Analyst Day with more.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Keith Weiss with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Keith Weiss with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: And maybe a couple for Eric on the impacts of CoreOS. Can you help us understand, from a sort of top line and bottom line perspective, how should we think about sort of what CoreOS did in terms of billings in Q4? Maybe you could help us in sort of parsing
componenttext: And maybe a couple for Eric on the impacts of CoreOS. Can you help us understand, from a sort of top line and bottom line perspective, how should we think about sort of what CoreOS did in terms of billings in Q4? Maybe you could help us in sort of parsing out the operating margin impacts heading into FY '19 versus kind of what the underlying core, excuse the pun, but underlying like core Red Hat would have done excluding CoreOS.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, Keith, so as you can imagine, I mean,  obviously, as part of the acquisition, any of the deferred revenue gets written off, so you're essentially building up that book of business from scratch as we go into the new year. So what I would say i
componenttext: Yes. I mean, Keith, so as you can imagine, I mean,  obviously, as part of the acquisition, any of the deferred revenue gets written off, so you're essentially building up that book of business from scratch as we go into the new year. So what I would say is the add of top line revenue growth from CoreOS is not going to be significantly material. From an expense standpoint, as we mentioned in my prepared remarks, we've got over 100 basis points of expense, and you all can calculate that pretty quickly in terms of what we're going to be absorbing. And what that's really done for us though is helped us accelerate some of the technical hiring that we were going to be pursuing this year that we have essentially brought in at the end of last year. So we're extremely thrilled to have the CoreOS team with us. I think it does really help kind of -- as we've said before, it helps us reaffirm our #2 position within the Kubernetes project. But then also a lot of the automation that Jim was talking about in terms of containers, it has helped us accelerate a lot of that work. So we're bullish about it. But from an expense standpoint, it's over 100 basis points that we're going to be absorbing, which is why we're not taking the margin up for this year.

componenttext: Yes. Again, just in Q4, because we write off deferred revenue, it was -- I mean, rounds to 0. I don't know...

componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, it was just -- yes, it was several hundred thousand dollars. And again, we didn't really have a whole lot of lead time.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, it was just -- yes, it was several hundred thousand dollars. And again, we didn't really have a whole lot of lead time.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Murphy with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Murphy with JPMorgan.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: So Jim, the first time you used the word Kubernetes, it was so many years ago. I had never even heard the word. And at the time, I said, "Kuber what?" I didn't even know what it was. So just considering how early you were in identifying Kubernetes and pos
componenttext: So Jim, the first time you used the word Kubernetes, it was so many years ago. I had never even heard the word. And at the time, I said, "Kuber what?" I didn't even know what it was. So just considering how early you were in identifying Kubernetes and positioning for it and just now layering on top the acquisition of CoreOS, do you think that it solidifies Red Hat's positioning as the leader in Kubernetes capabilities? And just also as a part b, could you just update us on how Kubernetes is tracking relative to Docker and maybe where you think that balance is heading?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So couple things. Just real quick, contextually, there have only been 2 successful models for monetizing open source. One is the public cloud model, so Amazon runs as a public cloud offering, open source as a service and then Red Hat's model, w
componenttext: Yes, sure. So couple things. Just real quick, contextually, there have only been 2 successful models for monetizing open source. One is the public cloud model, so Amazon runs as a public cloud offering, open source as a service and then Red Hat's model, which is to be a significant contributor and offer on-premise and drive road maps for customers, et cetera, et cetera. So as we look at Kubernetes, we can talk about leadership or not, but if you look at the key people involved, it would be Google, which has the as a service way to monetize it, and Red Hat, which has our enterprise model. I do think public clouds will offer Kubernetes-as-a-service type offerings out there. There is such a far gap between our contribution and #3 that I think it would take somewhat a very long time to build a credible position to offer an on-premise or a hybrid Kubernetes offering. So I never want to say the war is won. We have competitors. But I think we have a very substantial lead in being able to help enterprise customers implement Kubernetes. Beyond Google and Red Hat, it is a far, far distant #3 in terms of contribution and influence on that community. So I do feel like we're in really, really, really good shape there. Relative to Docker, Docker's a different animal, right? So Docker is doing different things. It's now adopted Kubernetes as its approach to orchestrating Docker containers. We certainly also orchestrate Docker form headed containers, but I think we're more open to other types of container formats. So it's hard to compare them directly, so -- but I will say, I don't see Docker in many of the deals that we are involved in. I think they're a little bit more developer focused at this point. So I feel really good about our position across a container platform. Obviously, our position in Kubernetes has put us, I think, at a far lead over everyone else.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ittai Kidron with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ittai Kidron with Oppenheimer.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: I guess, just trying to focus on the core infrastructure business. It's been a while since we've seen such a great year-over-year growth in that category. Can you talk about patterns over there? And how much did cloud also contribute to that number?
componenttext: I guess, just trying to focus on the core infrastructure business. It's been a while since we've seen such a great year-over-year growth in that category. Can you talk about patterns over there? And how much did cloud also contribute to that number?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Just high level overall, contextually, as people look at hybrid cloud environments and/or modernizing applications to run in a -- on a more scale-out type infrastructure, those are primarily Linux-based workloads. So I do think part of what you're seeing
componenttext: Just high level overall, contextually, as people look at hybrid cloud environments and/or modernizing applications to run in a -- on a more scale-out type infrastructure, those are primarily Linux-based workloads. So I do think part of what you're seeing there is Linux winning share from Windows and also just in continuing to take out UNIX. So I think just this general move towards hybrid cloud is good for the core Linux business. As we said before, the public cloud business, which is revenue, the -- of the CCSP program, it continues to be very, very, very fast growth. It would be the fastest growing part of our portfolio. I think we saw was in Q2 or Q3 when it hit $200 million. In Q2, we said it's a $200 million run rate. We haven't really given it time, and we'll update that again. But you can kind of do the math around that. And it's a fast growing part of our business, so you should see it continuing to do.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, it's growing about twice as fast as the company. So when we hit the next milestone, we'll certainly announce that or when we're getting close to it, but I mean, it continues to grow nicely.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, it's growing about twice as fast as the company. So when we hit the next milestone, we'll certainly announce that or when we're getting close to it, but I mean, it continues to grow nicely.

componenttextpreview: And that's all RHEL. And it's all RHEL revenue just the way it's recognized.
componenttext: And that's all RHEL. And it's all RHEL revenue just the way it's recognized.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Siti Panigrahi with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Siti Panigrahi with Wells Fargo.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: A really impressive quarter, mainly looking at these 26 deals over $5 million, and then your App Dev and emerging technology, that grew 39%. I'm wondering how much -- how many deals out of that 26 were driven by these emerging technologies, those large de
componenttext: A really impressive quarter, mainly looking at these 26 deals over $5 million, and then your App Dev and emerging technology, that grew 39%. I'm wondering how much -- how many deals out of that 26 were driven by these emerging technologies, those large deals? And then when you look at this App Dev as well, so you talked about earlier 5% of your emerging technology and which grew 100% last year, I'm wondering if you have any color on that, too.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: So let me start with a couple of those. If you look at the big deals, we didn't really break it out for just the top 26. But virtually, all of those were -- have a lot of emerging tech in them. The largest deal was virtually entirely OpenShift. Actually,
componenttext: So let me start with a couple of those. If you look at the big deals, we didn't really break it out for just the top 26. But virtually, all of those were -- have a lot of emerging tech in them. The largest deal was virtually entirely OpenShift. Actually, 2 of the top 4 were primarily OpenShift. Two of the others in that -- I'm looking at the top 10 here. I'm just scanning. Two of the other were virtually entirely OpenStack. The others have kind of just kind of quite a mix of things in them. None of them, I would say, were heavy, heavy, heavy big RHEL. I mean, they all had some RHEL in them, but they were primarily the emerging tech in that kind of largest -- just skimming 10 deals.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Michael Turits with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll go next to Michael Turits with Raymond James.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: A question for Eric. If I look -- looks like EBIT growth was about 18% at the midpoint into next year and cash flow from ops, around 13%. So can you parse the headwinds to that in terms of linearity, duration and whether there's still a cash taxes impact
componenttext: A question for Eric. If I look -- looks like EBIT growth was about 18% at the midpoint into next year and cash flow from ops, around 13%. So can you parse the headwinds to that in terms of linearity, duration and whether there's still a cash taxes impact and whether or not by the time we get to fiscal '20, maybe those headwinds are behind us and we can grow it the same rate as EBIT?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Michael, I mean, one of the things I had in my prepared remarks, I mean, we did see this year some back-end loading of the deals in the fourth quarter closing the last couple weeks, in fact, even some of the last week of the quarter. So as we mode
componenttext: Yes. So Michael, I mean, one of the things I had in my prepared remarks, I mean, we did see this year some back-end loading of the deals in the fourth quarter closing the last couple weeks, in fact, even some of the last week of the quarter. So as we modeled out this upcoming year, we assumed similar assumptions as we went into both the second half of this year as well as into Q4 specifically. And again, as we've been saying is our deals are getting larger, getting more complex. You can appreciate the fact that with our customers, a lot more procurement organizations are getting involved, and they're -- and it will naturally skew some of this to the back-end part of the quarter. Where linearity is most important in Q4, obviously, is what gets closed in month 1 and month 2. We can certainly collect in month 3. But what's happening is we are seeing more activity closing in month 3, which then the cash flow's collected in the following year. So what I would say is we're assuming very similar trends for this upcoming Q4 as we had this past year. But certainly, we are going to -- we are working with the sales teams to see if we can get some of that activity, pull it out of month 3 into either month 1 or month 2 within the fourth quarter. So what I would say is we had really seen good progress in linearity Q1 through Q3, and then not too terribly unexpected, we saw a little bit of a bigger shift. Again, some of it's because of our year-end. And we would not do any kind of unusual discounting in the end of the year otherwise, so that kind of naturally force some of the stuff to happen in the last month of the quarter. So what I would say, Michael, is we are continuing to work on getting those a little bit more in parity. I do think you'll see improvement in FY '20. We are continuing to see a trail off of some of the cash taxes that we're going to have in this year as well, and then I expect that to taper off a little bit more as we get into FY '20. So I don't think they're going to get exactly in parity in FY '20, but they're going to start closing that gap a little bit more than what you're seeing now.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Raimo Lenschow with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Raimo Lenschow with Barclays.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit more towards the middleware as a service? Like how much of a trend is it, Jim? And how much of a [ head in ] will it be to the application portfolio? I guess, we're getting some more numbers about the emerging areas but just to m
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit more towards the middleware as a service? Like how much of a trend is it, Jim? And how much of a [ head in ] will it be to the application portfolio? I guess, we're getting some more numbers about the emerging areas but just to make sure that we kind of don't kind of read too much into it.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, look, I think we're -- we continue to take share in middleware. I just want to be clear, right, but we continue to do that. We've had a big focus though on our core platforms of OpenShift and OpenStack, and then we're driving attached to those pl
componenttext: Yes. No, look, I think we're -- we continue to take share in middleware. I just want to be clear, right, but we continue to do that. We've had a big focus though on our core platforms of OpenShift and OpenStack, and then we're driving attached to those platforms. And so as we do that, the middleware is kind of consumed as a service on OpenShift. And so I think in the medium term -- in the very short term, it's lead to some slightly lower growth rates on the middleware side, which has kind of pulled the App Dev and emerging down a bit. But I think what we're trying to say is, overall, OpenShift drives greater affinity to our middleware, and we see long term that growing quite nicely as we see a large percentage of our customers who buy OpenShift ultimately buy a fair amount of middleware from us. So there's a nice synergy across that, and so that's really what we're trying to say there.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt Hedberg with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt Hedberg with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Jim, a lot of focus is paid for OpenShift and rightly so. But I'm curious about OpenStack. I know you were at Mobile World Congress this year, and the telco vertical gets a lot of focus there. Curious though, are you seeing adoption for OpenStack in some
componenttext: Jim, a lot of focus is paid for OpenShift and rightly so. But I'm curious about OpenStack. I know you were at Mobile World Congress this year, and the telco vertical gets a lot of focus there. Curious though, are you seeing adoption for OpenStack in some other verticals as well? Maybe just an update there.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just looking to the math of it, I think 9 of our top 10 OpenStack deals in Q4 were not in the telco space. So we're actually seeing some nice traction, good bit in financial services, which is good to see and then kind of, again, a mix across other i
componenttext: Yes. Just looking to the math of it, I think 9 of our top 10 OpenStack deals in Q4 were not in the telco space. So we're actually seeing some nice traction, good bit in financial services, which is good to see and then kind of, again, a mix across other industries. So we're actually seeing good solid traction beyond telco. Now obviously, telco's big. We had -- we added up 50 material NFV wins with telcos through the course of the year, and those aren't pilots. These are people putting it into production for real workloads. And obviously, a lot of those are in anticipation of 5G. So yes, we're seeing really nice in telco, but I don't want that to overshadow the fact that we're seeing some solid traction in OpenStack. We had 1 big cloud provider, a big 8-figure deal that's using it both for enterprise and for cloud. But just kind of across the board, we're seeing some good solid OpenStack traction.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gregg Moskowitz with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gregg Moskowitz with Cowen and Company.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: And Jim, just a follow-up on that last question from Matt, and it's helpful to kind of hear some of the progress for OpenStack both telco and non-telco. As you look forward to fiscal '19, are you building any meaningful expectations for 5G and NFV-driven
componenttext: And Jim, just a follow-up on that last question from Matt, and it's helpful to kind of hear some of the progress for OpenStack both telco and non-telco. As you look forward to fiscal '19, are you building any meaningful expectations for 5G and NFV-driven deployments as part of the guide? How are you thinking about that as an opportunity over the next year as well as beyond that?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: No, frankly, nothing in the guide on 5G. But I think people are making decisions now and again, whether it is some POCs or as I talked about, these 50 wins from people are putting in production for specific VNFs for workloads, 5G is really still, I would
componenttext: No, frankly, nothing in the guide on 5G. But I think people are making decisions now and again, whether it is some POCs or as I talked about, these 50 wins from people are putting in production for specific VNFs for workloads, 5G is really still, I would say, at least 18 months to 2 years away before we'll see that take off. The reason we talk about it is obviously winning those now those will scale up big, but we're a ways away from seeing those in a big way. And so we have kind of, frankly, zero in for 5G in the plan for this year in the guide we gave you.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason Ader with William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Ader with William Blair.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: A quick one for Eric and then one for Jim. Eric, on the services and consulting lines, how should we think about the revenue growth rate in FY '19 versus FY '18? And then for Jim, OpenShift, obviously growing really fast. What are your priorities for Open
componenttext: A quick one for Eric and then one for Jim. Eric, on the services and consulting lines, how should we think about the revenue growth rate in FY '19 versus FY '18? And then for Jim, OpenShift, obviously growing really fast. What are your priorities for OpenShift in 2018 to maintain the kind of growth that you've been seeing and really expand more into the mainstream?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So Jason, it's Eric. So I mean, for services, I mean, clearly, we had a really strong year this year and as we've been saying that services is both a leading and lagging indicator in terms of the emerging technologies and the adoption of those.
componenttext: Yes, sure. So Jason, it's Eric. So I mean, for services, I mean, clearly, we had a really strong year this year and as we've been saying that services is both a leading and lagging indicator in terms of the emerging technologies and the adoption of those. As we go into FY '19, we see continued strength into the first half, so I would say it's -- we're going to see low 20% range in the first half, maybe a little bit lower than that, high teens. And then as we get into the second half of the year, as we continue to bring up the partner ecosystem, we expect it to moderate a bit down, a little bit more closer to the historic levels. It would be a little bit higher than our historic levels because it will take some time to get these partners up and running. But we have been working with a lot of our partner ecosystem to really get them up and scaling that out. So it's really going to be first half, continued strength. Second half will moderate a little bit closer towards more of our historical levels. So that's the way I would model it in -- for services.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: And that dovetails well into kind of OpenShift and  what we're doing. I think we've done a really good job of building kind of bottom-up groundswell momentum around OpenShift. And what that's starting to reflect in now is SIs coming to us wanting to build
componenttext: And that dovetails well into kind of OpenShift and  what we're doing. I think we've done a really good job of building kind of bottom-up groundswell momentum around OpenShift. And what that's starting to reflect in now is SIs coming to us wanting to build practices because they're seeing demand from their customers. And so you'll see us working a lot with partners to work to build out services capability around OpenShift. The other kind of thing that, well, we'll be able to talk about if you're at Summit is some of the large other kind of large industry players we're seeing interest in OpenShift, and so we should have some announcements at Summit that'll be interesting around that. So I'll whet your appetite to come see that as well. So really, it's building out the ecosystem now that we've built the kind of core kind of groundswell bottom-up demand. Now that the ecosystem's interested, we'll work to make sure that we light that up and enable it to further accelerate the business.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Adam Holt with MoffettNathanson.
componenttext: We'll go next to Adam Holt with MoffettNathanson.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: If I could just follow up on the OpenShift business, which obviously continues to be strong, I wanted to make sure I understand because I asked about this, I think, last quarter or 2 quarters ago, this idea of a transition in middleware. Are you seeing cu
componenttext: If I could just follow up on the OpenShift business, which obviously continues to be strong, I wanted to make sure I understand because I asked about this, I think, last quarter or 2 quarters ago, this idea of a transition in middleware. Are you seeing customers buy OpenShift and not buy middleware because they're able to build applications and deploy independent of the enterprise product? Or is it just a delivery model shift that ultimately ends up pulling along more of the middleware? And when would you expect, I guess, if you will, that shift to kind of normalize so that it's not a headwind for the OpenShift business?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's a bit of both because -- so the OpenShift platform, one of our real strengths is we can run both traditional staple applications and kind of cloud-native applications on the portfolio. So the traditional staple applications can pull Java, EAP
componenttext: Yes. So it's a bit of both because -- so the OpenShift platform, one of our real strengths is we can run both traditional staple applications and kind of cloud-native applications on the portfolio. So the traditional staple applications can pull Java, EAP, et cetera, out of the middleware portfolio, right. And so as people migrate applications, that migration often is off of WebSphere, WebLogic onto JBoss as the containerized application server on OpenShift. And so we get a lot of attach as people are doing brownfield for the more greenfield cloud native stuff. That's when stuff like BRMS, our rules engine, BPM, Fuse, so our kind of services that you need, whether that's messaging or integration or rules that you do need or API management on a new, more modern application, those get dragged through on the newer stuff. So it's a little bit on both and kind of depends on the use case. And a lot of companies will start with one, like I'm going to do my cloud native stuff, and then they justify and they pay for it by moving the traditional brownfield. But again, it depends a little bit on the customer. But across the board, I mean, once you're building on OpenShift, it does just make it easy, and we make it easy to consume any of the middleware services. And so that's why I think we're seeing a good tailwind there.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Abhey Lamba with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Abhey Lamba with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Jim, I wanted to revisit the OpenStack question. It's great to see traction outside of the telco vertical, and its use case in telco is well understood. It would be helpful if you can tell us what are the enterprises using OpenStack for and what type of g
componenttext: Jim, I wanted to revisit the OpenStack question. It's great to see traction outside of the telco vertical, and its use case in telco is well understood. It would be helpful if you can tell us what are the enterprises using OpenStack for and what type of growth do you expect there.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you look across the workloads, it is really for a whole set of different types of new workloads. So a lot of it's OpenShift running on OpenStack, so you have to have infrastructure underneath it if you want that to be on-premise. We're seeing a
componenttext: Yes. So if you look across the workloads, it is really for a whole set of different types of new workloads. So a lot of it's OpenShift running on OpenStack, so you have to have infrastructure underneath it if you want that to be on-premise. We're seeing a lot of OpenShift on OpenStack as people are building things out. We have some large, especially in financial services, just customers with kind of RHEL-based type workloads and as they're putting in new infrastructure, putting those on OpenStack as it's continued to mature. So it's a whole mix there. Trying to see I pull up some more specifics on the deals. But it really is kind of a whole mix of what I'll call general-purpose types of workloads. It's across government, technology, a lot of financial services in there as well. So and a lot of those -- actually, a chunk of those have RHEL as well in there, but a chunk of them are also OpenShift. So it really is kind of a whole mix of general-purpose workloads.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll go next to Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Jim, I was wondering if you can just talk a little bit about Ansible. When we talk to folks, obviously a lot of momentum and interest around OpenShift, but we've heard a lot about Ansible over the last, say, 6 to -- 3 to 6 months. I was wondering if you c
componenttext: Jim, I was wondering if you can just talk a little bit about Ansible. When we talk to folks, obviously a lot of momentum and interest around OpenShift, but we've heard a lot about Ansible over the last, say, 6 to -- 3 to 6 months. I was wondering if you can just add a little bit more color there, how it's performing against your expectations and how that plays into sort of the broader strategy on sort of the cloud side.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, hey, first off, thank you for asking. It's -- I mean, it really has been just a real standout performer for us. It continues to grow even faster than our very high expectations. We now have over a million nodes managed, so it's big and growing
componenttext: Yes. Well, hey, first off, thank you for asking. It's -- I mean, it really has been just a real standout performer for us. It continues to grow even faster than our very high expectations. We now have over a million nodes managed, so it's big and growing fast. We even -- we released a networking product or module really in the fall. We've already had 14 material Ansible wins. Of the large deals over $1 million, 53 had Ansible components in it. So it continues to grow really nicely. The nice part about it is it fits in broadly as you start thinking about automating containers, and so it fits in that space. It fits in the CI/CD pipeline and this whole DevOps world. It fits, again, as you start thinking about managing network devices or seeing the same thing with -- in security, where security is moving for people wanting to just have issues identified to having them remediated and Ansible's a particularly good technology to do that. So it's just a general-purpose technology that's easy to use, and so we're seeing that really across the board. So it fits well into our core cloud strategy, but it fits in kind of nicely in a number of scenarios. And especially as we start to see IoT in those types of use cases, it really is a great solution for a whole set of pain points there. So it's growing really, really well, and I think, we see nothing to say that's going to slow down.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018

componenttext: I also wanted to ask about Ansible. Consistent with Kirk, we've heard good things about it. But what are you -- when you're out there bidding on work, what is it typically that you're bidding against in terms of Ansible? In other words, what's the use case that customers are alternatively looking at if they're going to use different technologies in Ansible? And looking at the difference between the revenue guide and the cash flow guide, the cash flow's lower growth rate, but you didn't mention the duration as one of the impacts. And perhaps I missed it, but I just assumed that duration was also impacting the cash flow. If you could just clarify.

componenttext: Yes. The second's a little bit easier. I mean, duration -- it is actually in my prepared remarks. I mean, we do expect duration to shorten by a month.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2018 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the first one, that's a great question and I ask that question a lot. There isn't a really good simple answer to a competitor because, I would say, 80% of the time, that may be a little bit high but not too far off of that is Ansible versus do it
componenttext: Yes. On the first one, that's a great question and I ask that question a lot. There isn't a really good simple answer to a competitor because, I would say, 80% of the time, that may be a little bit high but not too far off of that is Ansible versus do it yourself, right, people writing scripts. It is manually people doing stuff. And so there isn't another technology -- I think very rare cases for more traditional type automation, a little bit of Chef or people like that, but the vast majority of the use cases are people saying, "Wow, I can automate this and take human labor costs out or have better security compliance in auditing because I now have the tool to do this versus humans running around." So really, the vast, vast majority of the cases, it's kind of replacing DIY, people running scripts and running around with fobs and that kind of stuff. So it's a great, great story because it really does help with workflows, automation, security, can take real cost out or, importantly, kind of help organizations scale without adding incremental resources. So it's rarely this technology versus that technology. It really is a kind of this versus DIY.
