headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Red Hat Second Quarter Fiscal Year '19 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions]  It is my pleasure to turn today's conference over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tom McCallum. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext:
Good 
day, everyone, and welcome to the Red Hat Second Quarter Fiscal Year '19 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions]  It is my pleasure to turn today's conference over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tom McCallum. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Red Hat's earnings call for the second quarter of fiscal 2019. Speakers for today's call will be Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; and Eric Shander, Executive Vice President and CFO. Our earnings press re
componenttext:
Thank you, David. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Red Hat's earnings call for the second quarter of fiscal 2019. Speakers for today's call will be Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; and Eric Shander, Executive Vice President and CFO. Our earnings press release was issued today after the market close and may be downloaded from redhat.com on the Investor Relations page. Also on this page, you will be able to find a copy of today's prepared remarks, a schedule of currency rates, and a slide deck with financial highlights and supplemental metrics that, along with our earnings release, include a reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP financial metrics.
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements about future financial performance and other future events or trends including guidance for the third quarter and full fiscal year '19. These statements are only predictions that are based on what we believe today and actual results may differ materially. These forward-looking statements are subject to the risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that could affect our financial results and performance of our business which we detailed -- which we discussed in detail in our filings with the SEC including today's earnings press release and the risk factors and other information contained in our most recent filing of 10-K and Form 10-Q. Red Hat assumes no obligation to update forward-looking statements that me make me on today's call. And with that, let me turn the call over to Jim.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and let me add my welcome to all of you joining us on today's call. In the second quarter, we continued to see demand from our customers around the globe as they focus on their digital transformation and hybrid cloud initiatives. We enable
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and let me add my welcome to all of you joining us on today's call. In the second quarter, we continued to see demand from our customers around the globe as they focus on their digital transformation and hybrid cloud initiatives. We enable our customers to succeed on these initiatives with our innovative solutions, award-winning support and global services. Our focus on customers helped us drive strong results in the second quarter where we delivered double digit growth in a number of our key financial metrics. Let me highlight a few of those for the quarter. 
Our total backlog, driven by strong bookings, grew 20% year-over-year. Our major geographic regions each grew bookings at double digit rates year-over-year. Our Application Development-related and other emerging technologies subscription revenues grew more than 30% year-over-year. And our services revenue, led by demand for OpenShift and Ansible consulting and training, grew 19% year-over-year in constant currency. 
Now let me give you some business metrics and highlights that demonstrate our continued traction with our customers and partners. Looking at our deals over $1 million this quarter, we closed a total of 73 deals over $1 million, up approximately 11% year-over-year. Within these deals, 11 were greater than $5 million, which is a record in a Q2 for us, and 1 deal was greater than $10 million. Cross-selling was strong in this cohort, over 76% of the top deals greater than $1 million including one or more components of our Application Development-related and emerging technologies offerings. One of the deals over $5 million was the largest services deal we have every closed in a quarter. This deal is with a global bank that is digitally transforming their payments business based on our integration middleware. Other top industry verticals within the deals greater than $1 million were financials services and the government sector. 
Looking at our top deals, 24 out of our top 25 deals that were up for renewal did so at an aggregate value of more than 100% of their previous value. The one deal that did not renew is a rare competitive loss to a legacy on-premise provider based on pricing. We're actively pursuing future business with this customer as they evaluate additional technologies, such as adopting OpenShift as a multi-cloud platform for the digital transformation of their business. Removing the one lost deal and using the next largest deal that did renew, the adjusted top 25 deals for the quarter would have renewed at an aggregate value of approximately 115% of their previous value. 
Looking more broadly across our customer base at 2 of our fastest-growing technologies, OpenShift and Ansible, let me provide you with some recent achievements to demonstrate the momentum we're seeing with our customers and partners. Last week, we announced a multi-partner relationship with HortonWorks and IBM Cloud Private to bring their big data and analytics products onto OpenShift. This is designed to enable customers to develop and run data-intensive applications on OpenShift, bringing them the power of hybrid cloud. Our Ansible technology reached approximately 2 million managed ned at the end of Q2, essentially doubling the number of managed nodes since Q4 of last year. Overall, both of these technologies added nearly 100 new customers each since Q1, and to continue to grow the median revenue per customer. 
In summary, we continue to drive significant adoption of our hybrid cloud technologies, even as we worked with the headwinds in middleware and our renewal base that we view and have previously disclosed -- discussed. We are being confident in our long-term competitive position and our proven ability to become increasingly strategic with our customers, as evidenced by our growth over the past several quarters with large customer engagements and momentum with our partners. I want to thank Red Hat associates for their tireless efforts in serving our customers. From building innovative solutions to delivering and supporting these technologies, we continue to stay focused on the success of our customers and delivering value every day. With that, let me turn the call over to Eric.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Let me also recognize and thank our global associates for their continued commitment to helping our customers succeed. Red Hat's ability to deliver business value has been a key driver to building a multibillion-dollar business, and the st
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. Let me also recognize and thank our global associates for their continued commitment to helping our customers succeed. Red Hat's ability to deliver business value has been a key driver to building a multibillion-dollar business, and the strength of our strategic customer relationships is one of the reasons we believe we are well positioned for the long term. Our performance this quarter was driven by the demand for our hybrid cloud technologies, which enabled us to deliver results that were in line with our guidance. 
As a result of our performance to date and the outlook for the remainder of the year, we are reaffirming our full year revenue growth in constant currency at 16% to 17%, along with our full year non-GAAP operating margin and cash flow. However, in U.S. dollars, we are lowering the full year revenue range by approximately $15 million to account solely for the change in FX rates, as the trend of weaker rates against the dollar for many of the major foreign currencies has continued to decline in recent months. For instance, Q2 total revenue would have been nearly $3 million higher using the FX rates from my June guidance. As such for this call, I will discuss our results in both USD and constant currency to provide a full view of the impact of foreign currency on our results. A more detailed view of our results and reconciliations of our -- for our non-GAAP measures to GAAP is included in our press release. 
I will now review our Q2 performance and business metrics before finishing with our outlook for Q3 and the rest of FY '19. In the second quarter, we delivered $823 million of total revenue, which was in line with guidance and represented growth of 14% in both USD and constant currency. As I mentioned earlier, this result of USD included a foreign exchange headwind of approximately $3 million from the rates used for guidance in June. 
Subscription revenue, which is mainly renewable, made up 88% of total revenue in Q2 and grew 13% in USD or 14% in constant currency. Subscription revenue for our infrastructure-related offerings was $527 million, an increase of 8% year-over-year in both USD and constant currency. This result was impacted by the lower available renewal base, which is largely RHEL, and the lower renewal value that Jim discussed in our top 25 renewals metric. Year-to-date, our infrastructure-related offerings are up 11% in USD and 10% in constant currency. 
Subscription revenue for our Application Development and other emerging technology offerings was $196 million, an increase of 31% year-over-year in both USD and constant currency. Within this portfolio, we continue to drive rapid growth in our emerging technologies, particularly in Ansible and OpenShift. As we discussed in the past, this growth has become somewhat offset by the moderation we are experiencing in our middleware offerings. We continue to believe that as customers shift their workloads to container environments, our middleware results and subscription revenue will benefit in the long run.  Overall, Application Development-related and emerging technologies revenue represented approximately 24% of total revenue, of 300 basis points from the year-ago quarter. 
Lastly, our services revenue of $100 million grew 17% year-over-year in USD or 19% in constant currency. The strong growth of our services business was driven by demand for training and consulting projects for our Ansible and OpenShift offerings. As I have mentioned before, our services business is both a leading and lagging indicator for the demand around our emerging products. We have seen that customers who buy both services and subscriptions tend to have a higher retention, which can lead to future opportunities and additional technology sales. 
Before we move to our non-GAAP operating income results, as a reminder, our non-GAAP operating income adjusts for noncash share-based compensation expenses, amortization of intangible assets, and transaction costs related to business combinations. Non-GAAP EPS adjusts for all these items as well as noncash interest expense related to the debt discount. 
On a non-GAAP basis, our Q2 operating income of $197 million grew 3% year-over-year with a non-GAAP operating margin of 23.9%. This quarterly result was 90 basis points higher than my June guidance and reflects some repositioning of hiring and marketing programs to the second half of the fiscal year. Net other income was $4 million and in line with guidance. 
Shifting to taxes and EPS, our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 22.3% for the quarter, which includes discrete tax benefits and the impact from certain nondeductible share based compensation expense. This resulted in non-GAAP EPS of $0.85, up 10% year-over-year and above my guidance as a result of the higher non-GAAP operating margin. 
Turning to the balance sheet, our total deferred revenue at quarter end was $2.4 billion, an increase of $341 million, representing growth of 17% in USD or 19% in constant currency over the same quarter a year ago. Our cash and investments at the end of the quarter was approximately $2.2 billion after repurchasing approximately $250 million or 1.7 million shares under our new share repurchase authorization, which has a remaining balance of approximately $750 million. In addition, we had approximately $245 million of total cash and outflows related to repayment of convertible notes. 
Moving to operational cash flow, with the adoption of the accounting standard ASU 2016-'15: Statement of Cash Flows, which requires us to classify the portion of the repayment of convertible notes attributable to debt discount as an operating cash flow as opposed to financing cash outflow. In an effort to appropriately reflect the cash generated from the operations of the business and for comparability of prior periods, we will provide both a GAAP and non-GAAP operating cash flow metric. 
Our GAAP operating cash flow, inclusive of the $32 million of repayments for the convertible notes attributable to the debt discount, was $133 million, down 7% year-over-year. The non-GAAP operating cash flow was $165 million, an increase of 16% year-over-year. 
Our FX-adjusted DSO was 61 days, up 5 days from Q2 of last year, driven by business linearity. The rolling 4 quarters billings proxy was $884 million, up 19% year-over-year. As a reminder, the rolling 4 quarters billings proxy is calculated by adding revenue plus change in deferred revenue on the cash flows statement for the last 4 quarters. 
Now I will discuss our total backlog for Q2, which includes billed contracts from the balance sheet, the new ASC 606 performance obligation disclosures, and our backlog for time and materials service bookings. Total backlog was up 20% year-over-year in Q2 for an estimated balance of $3.3 billion in USD. Our backlog in the quarter was a result of our bookings performance, with all of our regions at double-digit growth year-over-year. As for the regional mix in the second quarter, 54% of our bookings came from the Americas, 26% from EMEA and 20% from Asia Pacific. The second quarter route to market mix was 77% from the channel and 23% from our direct sales force compared to second quarter prior year's split of 79% and 21%. 
Our proxy for bookings duration was approximately 22 months, up nearly 1 month from Q2 last year. We attribute this to some customers choosing to extend their commitment to Red Hat with a longer-term strategic partnership. 
Now I'd like to turn to guidance. Our outlook assumes current business conditions and foreign exchange rates, which have generally continued to weaken against the dollar year-over-year. 
I will begin with our full year guidance, which assumes an incremental FX headwind to revenue of $15 million as compared to our prior guidance. As a result, we are adjusting our total revenue guidance in USD to $3.360 billion to $3.395 billion or a year-over-year growth range of 15% to 16% in U.S. dollars. In constant currency, we are reaffirming the year-over-year growth range of 16% to 17%.
From a profitability perspective, we are reaffirming our full year non-GAAP operating margin of 23.9%, which includes the necessary investments to drive future growth. 
We are planning an annual non-GAAP effective tax rate of 22.5% for FY '19 prior to discrete items, and our full year non-GAAP earnings per share to be approximately $3.45 to $3.49 per share. This assumes approximately $4 million per quarter for net other income and approximately 184 million diluted shares, which is lower due to share repurchases. 
Due to the difficulty of predicting the timing and amount of any future convertible note settlements, our guidance will now be on the non-GAAP operating cash flow for FY '19. Excluding the repayments of convertible notes that are attributable to the debt discount, our outlook remains unchanged for the full year. Non-GAAP operating cash flow is expected to be in a range of approximately $1.035 billion to $1.045 billion, which includes an incremental $10 million in tax payments. 
For Q3, we offer the following outlook. We expect revenue to be in the range of $848 million to $856 million, which is up approximately 13% to 14% in USD and 15% to 16% in constant currency. We expect non-GAAP operating margin of approximately 24%. 
We expect non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.87 with a 22.5% tax rate prior to discrete items. This assumes approximately $4 million in Q3 for net other income and 184 million diluted shares. 
We will continue our practice of not providing quarterly cash flow guidance, but please note that it can be variable depending upon individual payments or collections. 
Looking forward, we remain excited that Red Hat is increasingly viewed as a top strategic IT partner to the world's leading companies as they execute on their digital transformation and hybrid cloud initiatives and we remain committed to our customers success. David, at this point, please open up the call for questions.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Walter Pritchard with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Walter Pritchard with Citi.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: A question for Eric, maybe a two-parter bit, just on the RHEL growth, infrastructure growth at 8%. You talked about renewals driving that softness in revenue. I guess we haven't seen in the past the renewal business drive such deceleration in RHEL. Could
componenttext: A question for Eric, maybe a two-parter bit, just on the RHEL growth, infrastructure growth at 8%. You talked about renewals driving that softness in revenue. I guess we haven't seen in the past the renewal business drive such deceleration in RHEL. Could you help us understand what's going on this year versus what you had that in the past? And then should we expect that business -- it sounds like if it's a renewal thing, as you get through the renewals out, it would be accelerating. Can you help us understand the timing of that reacceleration?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: yes, sure, Walter. So there's actually a couple of components impacting the RHEL growth. the lower renewal base -- has impacted, because a majority of our renewals are RHEL, have a significant amount of RHEL content. The other thing is as Jim had mentione
componenttext: yes, sure, Walter. So there's actually a couple of components impacting the RHEL growth. the lower renewal base -- has impacted, because a majority of our renewals are RHEL, have a significant amount of RHEL content. The other thing is as Jim had mentioned, we did have this larger competitive loss within the quarter, which impacted -- which did have an impact, as well as we also had a project descope from the army that impacted the growth in RHEL as well. So we had a couple of components other than just the lower renewal base. In terms of right now, the way that we're looking at the bookings and the momentum we've seen in the field and the pipeline, we do believe that we've bottomed out in terms of the RHEL growth slowing down. And that's our expectation from here through the second half of the year and into next year, that we will see a reacceleration in the growth rate.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Karl Keirstead with Deutsche Bank

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Maybe this question is for Eric. Eric, even though you don't disclose your middleware business, you've spoken in the past about these piece of the Red Hat revenue mix growing in the 9% to 10% ZIP code in fiscal '19. Given the quarter you just put up, is t
componenttext: Maybe this question is for Eric. Eric, even though you don't disclose your middleware business, you've spoken in the past about these piece of the Red Hat revenue mix growing in the 9% to 10% ZIP code in fiscal '19. Given the quarter you just put up, is that still your expectation for the middleware growth rate this year?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sure, Karl. Yes. So we did -- what we've been saying is we expect the middleware growth to moderate close to where the industry is, anywhere from the 8% to 10% range. We did say that this quarter, and we certainly expect that as we go into the second half
componenttext: Sure, Karl. Yes. So we did -- what we've been saying is we expect the middleware growth to moderate close to where the industry is, anywhere from the 8% to 10% range. We did say that this quarter, and we certainly expect that as we go into the second half of the year. So we -- nothing has changed in terms of the growth rate from a middleware perspective.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Zane Chrane with Bernstein Research.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Zane Chrane with Bernstein Research.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: as well question for Eric or Jim, either one. When we look at growth in RHEL, how much of the growth is driven by a new customer adoption versus expansion inside your existing base? And then when these new customers, where are they choosing to deploy that
componenttext: as well question for Eric or Jim, either one. When we look at growth in RHEL, how much of the growth is driven by a new customer adoption versus expansion inside your existing base? And then when these new customers, where are they choosing to deploy that in terms of on-premise versus public cloud deployments?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'll start that and I'll certainly have Jane -- have Jim add a little more color to it. So certainly for new customers, we are seeing both on-premise and in the cloud. Most of this typically start on-premise. For existing customers, we're seeing e
componenttext: Yes, so I'll start that and I'll certainly have Jane -- have Jim add a little more color to it. So certainly for new customers, we are seeing both on-premise and in the cloud. Most of this typically start on-premise. For existing customers, we're seeing expansion as customers' IT footprints are continuing to expand. And I've shown several of these examples during our previous Analyst Days of not only do we see customers embracing and then adopting emerging technologies, but a lot of it has also a pull-through effect in terms of the RHEL requirements as well. So ...

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean just to add to that. So yes, we haven't actually looked at it quite like a number that way. only reason I say that because the cloud revenue is immediate revenue. And obviously, our normal subscription business is lumpier when we do either 1-
componenttext: Yes, I mean just to add to that. So yes, we haven't actually looked at it quite like a number that way. only reason I say that because the cloud revenue is immediate revenue. And obviously, our normal subscription business is lumpier when we do either 1- or 3-year deals. I think a lot of our new smaller customers are coming in via cloud. We have some really nice growth there, it's still growing at more than twice the growth rate of the company. So yes, a lot of that we believe this new business. The core business, customers are continuing to renew, we give you those numbers. The odd part, just to remind everyone, we started about 2.5 years ago focusing on trying to do multiyear deals to try to basically get our customers kind of into multiyear engagement, so our sales force could focus on net new. Well obviously 3 years, 2.5 years into that, yes, we've done our best of get people in 3-year deals. So our renewal base is quite small relative to where it's been in the past. And it's at renewal where we typically takeup the size of those relationships. So yes, fewer renewals means less takeup in these last couple of quarters. With again, I mean we're seeing it from both. We still see a lot of growth with our existing customers. And as we talked about in the past, customers who are adopting cloud tend to grow their RHEL footprint faster than those who aren't.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it, and a quick follow-up ...
componenttext: Okay, got it, and a quick follow-up ...

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: I do apologize. We will take our next question from Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: I do apologize. We will take our next question from Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: I guess, Jim, could you just talk about this year obviously, you knew coming in the year that you have some smaller renewal portfolio to build off of. So can you just talk about the net new business growth that you've seen? Because the billings this quart
componenttext: I guess, Jim, could you just talk about this year obviously, you knew coming in the year that you have some smaller renewal portfolio to build off of. So can you just talk about the net new business growth that you've seen? Because the billings this quarter obviously looked pretty good. And specifically within the emerging products segment, given the drag on JBoss, one can infer that things -- OpenShift, Ansible might actually be going better than you might have expected at beginning of the year? so I'm curious [ on your take ]  on net new business momentum, and then some of the smaller products like OpenShift and Ansible relative to expectations.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, you hit on a good point there. If you look overall, given the overall backlog growth and the fact that we didn't have as great renewals, is that we're seeing some really good traction with new products to deliver what we delivered. And a lot
componenttext: Yes. I mean, you hit on a good point there. If you look overall, given the overall backlog growth and the fact that we didn't have as great renewals, is that we're seeing some really good traction with new products to deliver what we delivered. And a lot of that is the new products, like we're seeing really, really pleased with OpenShift and with Ansible. We talked about adding -- we don't break those numbers out, but adding over 100 customers in each in the quarter is pretty significant and shows the size of that momentum. We didn't give a lot of stats on OpenStack, but it continued to grow nicely as well. So across all 3 of those, we're seeing some really nice growth and some really, really good traction. Yes, I had a plan where we are expecting to be, yes.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Kirk, it's Eric, some additional color around the size of the deal and the traction. So in Q1, we articulated just the deals between 250,000 and 1 million, that was growing over 130%. This quarter, the number of deals between 250,000 and 1 millio
componenttext: Yes. And Kirk, it's Eric, some additional color around the size of the deal and the traction. So in Q1, we articulated just the deals between 250,000 and 1 million, that was growing over 130%. This quarter, the number of deals between 250,000 and 1 million grew at over 120%. So as you can see, we're still seeing a lot of momentum in the mid-section of the deals and the size of those deals. So we do expect, as we've been saying, that a lot of these deals will start smaller. And it will certainly take a couple of years to cultivate them into larger, strategic enterprise customers, but that absolutely is the strategy that we're on.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Michael Turits with Raymond James.
componenttext: Next question is from Michael Turits with Raymond James.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: This is actually Robert on for Michael. Jim, can you just talk about any changes that you're seeing in the competitive environment, when it comes to RHEL cloud deployments and especially Amazon cloud ?
componenttext: This is actually Robert on for Michael. Jim, can you just talk about any changes that you're seeing in the competitive environment, when it comes to RHEL cloud deployments and especially Amazon cloud ?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: I don't think we've seen anything new there. I think we're -- the cloud business is growing very nicely, and if you look at kind of cloud by cloud, our growth rate's pretty consistent with the growth rates of the cloud. And so that to be sense that we are
componenttext: I don't think we've seen anything new there. I think we're -- the cloud business is growing very nicely, and if you look at kind of cloud by cloud, our growth rate's pretty consistent with the growth rates of the cloud. And so that to be sense that we are maintaining share or in some of them, we're growing faster. So where either maintaining or growing share across the major cloud. So to me, that's a good sign and that's on the CCSPP. Since one of the other pieces that we've seen as well is we've had some very large customers who have rolled out off CCSPP and have done subscriptions with Red Hat because they want to have a direct relationship. So that's the direction we like to see things move. So we feel pretty good overall and watch that carefully. But I don't see -- if I look at our growth rates cloud by cloud versus the clouds' growth rates, we do feel that we're certainly maintaining or growing share.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Raimo Lenschow with Barclays
componenttext: Our next question comes from Raimo Lenschow with Barclays

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Eric, a quick question for me, like if you look at this slightly better leverage this quarter. You talked about hiring some initiatives getting pushed out in the second half. Could you double-click on that little bit? Is that kind of you managing the busi
componenttext: Eric, a quick question for me, like if you look at this slightly better leverage this quarter. You talked about hiring some initiatives getting pushed out in the second half. Could you double-click on that little bit? Is that kind of you managing the business as you know, -- as you knew what your revenue was during the quarter? Or what are the drivers there?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Raimo. And there was a bit certainly as you go through the quarter, and as we talked about this one competitive loss it was not lost until the very end of the quarter. So we were certainly fighting to keep this at the end of the quarter. Howe
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Raimo. And there was a bit certainly as you go through the quarter, and as we talked about this one competitive loss it was not lost until the very end of the quarter. So we were certainly fighting to keep this at the end of the quarter. However, having said that, as you can imagine, as we look at some of the other trends in the business, we did a slight pullback in certain areas. Certainly not in our sales area, because that's key area of investment and continued investment. So there was a little bit of cost management as we went through the quarter. Essentially as you think about the guide for the rest of the year, I expect the margin essentially to be flat as we go into Q3. And then it will pop up into Q4 because some of the marketing spend that we have will be actually done in Q3 versus Q4. So we're going to continue to actively manage the costs side. But at the same time too, I just want to emphasize that we are continuing to be very, very mindful about making the appropriate investments into our more strategic areas. So a lot of those investments come, as we get efficiencies and productivity, in other spaces within the company. So we absolutely will continue to invest in the strategic areas as we go through this year and certainly into next year. But we are taking a very active position, I am certainly, in terms of how we're managing the costs.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Kash with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is from Kash with Bank of America.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: I'm just curious to get your -- get a little bit more perspective on the renewal base you talked about with respect to the deceleration of the OpenShift business. I know you're certainly pointing to that business reaccelerating. Typically when we look at
componenttext: I'm just curious to get your -- get a little bit more perspective on the renewal base you talked about with respect to the deceleration of the OpenShift business. I know you're certainly pointing to that business reaccelerating. Typically when we look at Q1 to Q2, there's been a nice sequential growth in the RHEL business. This time, it seems the magnitude of that seemed to be a little surprising. So if you could just drill into that a little bit and also help us understand what is happening there really emerging technologies side of the middleware component, the PaaS side? A little bit more color there would be useful.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, so thanks, Kash. I'll start, and then Jim can give a little more color on the business side of it. Just as a reminder, Q1, our billings, we were at 9%. So you're really seeing, from a revenue perspective, that really flow through. So that did have an
componenttext: Yes, so thanks, Kash. I'll start, and then Jim can give a little more color on the business side of it. Just as a reminder, Q1, our billings, we were at 9%. So you're really seeing, from a revenue perspective, that really flow through. So that did have an impact to RHEL. And then obviously this quarter, as we looked at the bookings in the billings, the renewal base continue to be a little bit of a headwind, as well as just reemphasizing both the project descope that was out of our control that was specific to the army, as well as this one loss -- this one competitive loss, they did also both have a fair amount of content for RHEL. so all of these impacted us for the quarter, which again gives us confidence that as we look at the pipeline, as we look at to go into the second half, we do see a reacceleration in the growth.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean a little bit on PaaS, I mean, I would say obviously the vast majority of our revenue is backed when we come into a quarter. So coming into Q1 where we were light than we wanted to be on billings and backlog, kind of rolled through this -- obvi
componenttext: Yes. I mean a little bit on PaaS, I mean, I would say obviously the vast majority of our revenue is backed when we come into a quarter. So coming into Q1 where we were light than we wanted to be on billings and backlog, kind of rolled through this -- obviously we had a lot stronger quarter this quarter in growth there. And so we had some better visibility looking forward into RHEL. And so we do think this is kind of the bottom there. Related to PaaS, we're seeing great traction. I mean we had over 100 new customers for OpenShift. Not only is it customers, it's also partners. And so unlike some other software companies that will pay tens of millions of dollars to enable SIs, we focus on bottom-up demand generation. And so we've gotten really good bottom-up support for OpenShift. And now the large global system integrators are all building practices around OpenShift, and I think that also leads to an incremental traction. I think the Microsoft deal which we announced, the relationship that we announced back in Summit, is -- has raised awareness that it has helped as well. So I was in Europe last week. And I think out of that maybe 30 or so customer meetings I had, 20-something of them were about OpenShift in particular. It really is a topic that people want to understand and figure out how to do in containers. I would say, just editorial comment, I also think one of the things that has slowed RHEL growth a bit is customers want to talk about containers. And we need to continue to talk about RHEL is part of that portfolio. And I think the shiny object syndrome gets us all, the EMEA included, where we're talking about OpenShift and Ansible because there is so much traction around them. But overall, I -- it's hard to find a customer that's not looking at or starting to use OpenShift in some way, which is great to see.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Matt Hedberg with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Matt Hedberg with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: It's [ Dan ] for Matt . Jim, maybe could you update us on the overall spending environment, any changes in customer buying behavior in the back half?
componenttext: It's [ Dan ] for Matt . Jim, maybe could you update us on the overall spending environment, any changes in customer buying behavior in the back half?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, customers seem to still feel good about the economy and where it's going. I think the concern about the trade war within China is spooking some people. But at this point, I wouldn't say I've seen that ripple in the spending. so it still feels
componenttext: No. I mean, customers seem to still feel good about the economy and where it's going. I think the concern about the trade war within China is spooking some people. But at this point, I wouldn't say I've seen that ripple in the spending. so it still feels pretty good. Our Q2, because it ends in August and there are a lot of vacations, et cetera, I would say typically less senior-level discussions in a Q2 than I would have in Q1 or Q3. So I don't want to overstate my confidence in saying that, in the sense that haven't talked to as many CEOs about their overall thoughts there. So again, it still feels robust. But again, a little bit of that -- I don't want to overstate kind of given it's the Q2 and ending in August and kind of less time directly out there with customers that I typically have.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: I had a question about your comments about RHEL growth, right? So it went from 11% constant currency last quarter to 8% this quarter. You're talking about a reacceleration. But I think the big question is, is that -- does that reacceleration you're expect
componenttext: I had a question about your comments about RHEL growth, right? So it went from 11% constant currency last quarter to 8% this quarter. You're talking about a reacceleration. But I think the big question is, is that -- does that reacceleration you're expecting, that's a 10 as we normalize the renewal base that you're talking about? Or is this going to go back to what you used to say, which was low, kind of the low teens growth rate? Because I'm just trying to get a sense for when you're talking about reacceleration off of what is a very low base.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, heather, I'll start on that. I think we'll see as we get into next year, bluntly, the -- yes, I do think we'll see reaccelerate through this year. Exactly where that ends up, hard to exactly say. As we get into next year, we have a much larger renewa
componenttext: Yes, heather, I'll start on that. I think we'll see as we get into next year, bluntly, the -- yes, I do think we'll see reaccelerate through this year. Exactly where that ends up, hard to exactly say. As we get into next year, we have a much larger renewal base. And since OpenShift's continuing its momentum, which I hope it does, I would say it can easily accelerate quite a bit. But we are running into a little bit of a sales capacity issue. And so the better OpenShift does and the more time we're spending on that, the less time we're selling RHEL. So the demand is clearly there, the market is clearly there. And so I mean given the size of the renewal base, I think it will expand a little bit more than that, but I want to be a little bit guarded just as people are -- there's just so much momentum around OpenShift right now, that it does kind of eat into selling time on RHEL. So clearly, the -- if you look at the overall trends from move of workloads to Windows to Linux and the overall growth of workloads certainly feel like it should reaccelerate above 10 and back into the teens. But again, our other products can at times start to push that out a little bit, which is part of the dynamic that we've seen with the strength that OpenShift affecting RHEL a bit. Now that's a long answer, but we feel really good about the macro trends around Linux. And it's about ability of us to have the bandwidth to pick it all up.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. And just as a reminder, and we continue to always say this, but Linux is containers. So even as Jim is accelerating the fact that customers are starting to buy OpenShift, right? Linux -- RHEL is embedded into that. We certainly don't break it out, bu
componenttext: Yes. And just as a reminder, and we continue to always say this, but Linux is containers. So even as Jim is accelerating the fact that customers are starting to buy OpenShift, right? Linux -- RHEL is embedded into that. We certainly don't break it out, but we don't necessarily view it as a bad thing as OpenShift has continued to gain momentum and gain traction. Because by default, they are using RHEL in that product. So just -- we'll just reiterate what we've been saying, that's a good thing.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Right. It is a different way to deliver the operating system. It's not like OpenShift runs on top of RHEL. OpenShift is RHEL.
componenttext: Right. It is a different way to deliver the operating system. It's not like OpenShift runs on top of RHEL. OpenShift is RHEL.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: So that is a good thing. So how that mix works depends on the relative adoption rate of containers.
componenttext: So that is a good thing. So how that mix works depends on the relative adoption rate of containers.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Morgan Stanley
componenttext: Our next question comes from Morgan Stanley

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: This is Sanjit for Keith. I had 2 small ones, if I might. First on the 5G cycle, can you give us an update on how you feel the open sky portfolio is positioned for the oncoming 5G cycle? And any sense on timing of where you might start to see large deals
componenttext: This is Sanjit for Keith. I had 2 small ones, if I might. First on the 5G cycle, can you give us an update on how you feel the open sky portfolio is positioned for the oncoming 5G cycle? And any sense on timing of where you might start to see large deals come through? That would be helpful. And then on JBoss and the middleware portfolio, there's a lot of elements within the middleware portfolio. Is the weakness you're seeing particularly in the application side? And would you expect the integration of pieces like Fuse to actually see potentially more demand as we -- as customers move to things like OpenShift and next-generation application or architectures?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, so a couple of things there. In terms of the 5G cycle, I'm not an expert in telco, so I don't want to kind of overstate that. We have a lot of work going on with some major telcos surrounded. So I think OpenStack is very well positioned there. I've a
componenttext: Yes, so a couple of things there. In terms of the 5G cycle, I'm not an expert in telco, so I don't want to kind of overstate that. We have a lot of work going on with some major telcos surrounded. So I think OpenStack is very well positioned there. I've also been -- amazed is probably the wrong word, but really surprised at the amount of traction we're having on containers with those tail telcos as well. So it's not just a matter of the infrastructure, it's the application platform at the edge. If you have a 5G network, you kind of need applications at the edge. That's the differentiation that telcos have. So we have a significant amount of engineering effort working with the telcos on OpenShift as well. timing of that, again those deals continue to grow. We've had 14 deals with OpenStack over $1 million, which is up nicely from last year. Not all of those are in telco, but we did have some sizable telco wins. And we have I think 4 significant NFC wins with telcos in the quarter. I -- again, how fast those things scale, I'll leave that up to experts to talk about, but we feel really good about where that is.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Is there a second part?
componenttext: Is there a second part?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, there was a JBoss question -- how -- Oh yes, JBOss absolutely. This is primarily an EAP-related thing. The other products sit nicely on top of OpenShift. And so as OpenShift grows, that increases the market for those. Just -- we mentioned the over $5
componenttext: Yes, there was a JBoss question -- how -- Oh yes, JBOss absolutely. This is primarily an EAP-related thing. The other products sit nicely on top of OpenShift. And so as OpenShift grows, that increases the market for those. Just -- we mentioned the over $5 million services deal that is a ramp for a bank around integration products. That includes very little of the integration products until that's up and running. But that's a good example of a bank that's also a big OpenShift user now looking to do some significant work on this on the integration side. So yes, this is primarily around EAP that we're seeing in the moderation affecting the overall app dev and emerging growth.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mark Murphy with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Murphy with JPMorgan.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: I'm curious at what point do you think that tide would begin to turn on the renewal cycle. I know you mentioned next year, it's in better shape. But if we were to try to circle a quarter in our models where the renewal cycle would begin to switch from a h
componenttext: I'm curious at what point do you think that tide would begin to turn on the renewal cycle. I know you mentioned next year, it's in better shape. But if we were to try to circle a quarter in our models where the renewal cycle would begin to switch from a headwind to a tailwind, I guess I'm wondering next May, next August, if you could help us with that? And then also the -- I think you said the competitive loss did not happen until quarter end, but I believe you said it impacted the RHEL growth of 8%. And I guess I don't understand, if there were daily ratable rev rec and it continued there until quarter end, I guess I'm not understanding then how that impacted the revenue growth. If you could just clarify that.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start with the second one. So typically in these large deals, there's been some degree of overdeployment. So there's always some true-up revenues that's in there. And so they're -- and those [connections] would be more material than you realize.
componenttext: Yes, I'll start with the second one. So typically in these large deals, there's been some degree of overdeployment. So there's always some true-up revenues that's in there. And so they're -- and those [connections] would be more material than you realize. And so -- because we lost it, I didn't get into the detailed details of the flows around that. But there was a, across the portfolio, a couple of million dollar -- several million-dollar impact across that. So it was fairly significant in terms of overall revenue how much of that was true-up versus the last day at the end of the quarter. Eric, you may add details.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, Mark, a lot of it really had to do with the revenue true-up. So during this period, the customer was in the process of phasing out their activity and they were in the process of making some decision. So had they made the decision to stay with
componenttext: Yes. I mean, Mark, a lot of it really had to do with the revenue true-up. So during this period, the customer was in the process of phasing out their activity and they were in the process of making some decision. So had they made the decision to stay with us, there would have certainly been a retroactive adjustment in terms of the revenue and us trueing that up. But that was not the case in the situation. So unfortunately, it was this competitive loss to a legacy on-prem provider, and that certainly was unfortunate. But as Jim said, we're already working some new leads with this customer, but it really had to do with just the way the revenue would have been trued up.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: The second part was when the tide would turn on the number of renewals next year or quarter?
componenttext: The second part was when the tide would turn on the number of renewals next year or quarter?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Mark, as we're looking at that, I would tell you the latter part of the first quarter, certainly as we get into the second quarter, you'll start to see the renewals pick up. Now I say that, and as I mentioned previously, one of the things that mak
componenttext: Yes. So Mark, as we're looking at that, I would tell you the latter part of the first quarter, certainly as we get into the second quarter, you'll start to see the renewals pick up. Now I say that, and as I mentioned previously, one of the things that makes the renewals analysis challenging for all of us is that assumes that customers don't come to us and decide that they want to co-term something early. So certainly if we have a customer that comes in the second half of this year where they have something that's going to renew next year, but if they come to us and say, "Gee, we like to do a bigger engagement and we'd like to infuse some OpenShift or OpenStack," et cetera, we absolutely would do that deal. And that would throw some of this off, and there is a fair amount of that as that happens. Certainly the one thing we're not going to do is pull in deals ourselves. But if a customer has a business need and they want to expand their scope with us, we absolutely will entertain them. So barring any big go terms happening in the second half of this year, I would say in your models, I would assume the latter part of Q1, and then really as you get into Q2 onwards is when we see it pick back up.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Alex with Piper Jaffray
componenttext: Our next question is from Alex with Piper Jaffray

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: This is Taylor Reiners on for Alex. Just wondering if you think about the renewal base in the back half, I was wondering on what are your thoughts on the cross-selling opportunities that are being impacted? And as your renewal base starts to normalize, ho
componenttext: This is Taylor Reiners on for Alex. Just wondering if you think about the renewal base in the back half, I was wondering on what are your thoughts on the cross-selling opportunities that are being impacted? And as your renewal base starts to normalize, how are you handicapping the opportunity for reacceleration in your emerging offerings, just given the larger renewal base to sell into?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: It's a mixed bag. The reason I -- I mean, it's we really like the renewal, but that's the time to cross-sell and upsell, which is really, really nice. But some of the time on that deal is spent on the renewal of the components around it, where the reason
componenttext: It's a mixed bag. The reason I -- I mean, it's we really like the renewal, but that's the time to cross-sell and upsell, which is really, really nice. But some of the time on that deal is spent on the renewal of the components around it, where the reason we originally started 2.5 years ago trying to get people these 3-year deals is it frees up more time to sell net new. that may be efficient to sell and it may be shorter like 1-year deals, but it does -- it kind of creates more of kind of clarity and focus in our go-to-market organization. So hard to say which of those actually kind of weighs out in terms of the emerging. I would say on balance that the team, they're going to say attach and growing cross-sell, upsell around the renewal is the more efficient way to see that growth. But again, it is more sales time spent on that renewal as well than on the new business. So yes, there might be a little bit of an impact there accelerating the other associated with it. But the big impact is those renewals typically grow, and we give you the data on that. So bigger renewal base does a lot to especially help RHEL growth.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we did have, certainly in our prepared remarks, Q2 was over 76% cross-selling, which certainly demonstrates that. But just as a reminder as we said, as we're going into this next tranche of smaller customers, and they're not necessarily small
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we did have, certainly in our prepared remarks, Q2 was over 76% cross-selling, which certainly demonstrates that. But just as a reminder as we said, as we're going into this next tranche of smaller customers, and they're not necessarily small customers, but customers that are spending smaller amounts us, those will typically start out as a RHEL customer, and as we continue to work with them, start expanding beyond that. So beyond the existing renewal base that we have, part of what we're doing very intentionality is going to that next tier of customers to be able to get certainly and grow an additional set of enterprise customers as we go forward. So some of this is going to be layering it on. But I think as Jim said, I mean I think there is nice cross-selling opportunities across the board with the existing renewal base that we have.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Keith Bachman with BMO.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Keith Bachman with BMO.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dig down a little bit more on JBoss. you've mentioned that you see improved renewal cycle for RHEL. And I'm just wondering your thoughts on JBoss as we look out into 2019. And part of the context of the question is you mentioned last quarter t
componenttext: I wanted to dig down a little bit more on JBoss. you've mentioned that you see improved renewal cycle for RHEL. And I'm just wondering your thoughts on JBoss as we look out into 2019. And part of the context of the question is you mentioned last quarter that some of your competitors were very aggressive on pricing. So do you think JBoss flattens out next year, improves? Or could there be more competitive pressure? And then the follow-up question on RHEL, you mentioned you had a loss. And implicit in your discussions is that you feel really good about RHEL's opportunities. But the loss was based on I think an on-premise deal on pricing. What makes you convinced that there won't be some more very aggressive pricing by some of your competitors trying to maintain their legacy base? That's it for me.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, let me -- I'll start with the second, and I'll go to the first. over the last 3 years, we talked about the top 25 renewals of the -- each quarter, and that's 300 deals. We've only now lost 2. And the one that we lost, we did an even bigger midd
componenttext: Yes. Well, let me -- I'll start with the second, and I'll go to the first. over the last 3 years, we talked about the top 25 renewals of the -- each quarter, and that's 300 deals. We've only now lost 2. And the one that we lost, we did an even bigger middleware deal with after. When we lost people in the past, we have typically won them back. It sounds logical to say, "Oh, I can get a cheaper price for my Linux."  But what production customers find is they don't get that quality of software and certainly not support that they get from us. And so honestly, I don't mind losing one every now and then. If we win them all, then we're probably overpricing. And we have a really good track record of winning them back as they've had a chance to experience the other. And so given that that and how rare the losses are and how often the losses have come back, and even they come reference customers for us. We also always want to take competitors seriously. But in terms of over looking at this one deal, I wouldn't kind of overly focus on that relative to our long-term history of competing with others. In terms of middleware, you hit on a good point. the same way that we did multiyear deals on RHEL, lots of those deals on stand-alone JBoss deals were multiyear deals 3 years ago as well. So there was a lot of renewal on JBoss coming up for next year as well. And so again, that's -- that will be a good opportunity for us to continue to expand those.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from John DiFucci with Jefferies
componenttext: Our next question is from John DiFucci with Jefferies

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: My question is for Jim. Jim, Red Hat's done a really good job over the years. I've questioned you  a lot, but you've really done it, and you dominate the Linux market. And more recently, you moved aggressively to growth markets. And you currently become -
componenttext: My question is for Jim. Jim, Red Hat's done a really good job over the years. I've questioned you  a lot, but you've really done it, and you dominate the Linux market. And more recently, you moved aggressively to growth markets. And you currently become -- relative in those markets, [you've been] leading them. But -- and this is asked in a [indiscernible]  manner, it's really usually not a good sign when a growth business starts to talk about the effects of the renewal cycle, the reasons of moderating growth. And I'm just I think a lot of us are just wondering is there something else happening there in the Linux business? And I don't know. I don't know what it could be. like there's people have fear at times that people are going to start in the public cloud, start to use sort of the free versions or not unpaid Linux. is there a saturation on-premise? Is there anything else happening here? Or is it really -- or is that just sort in this renewal cycle?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. we'll first off, thanks for the complements. I was beginning to think somebody was impersonating you. So I appreciate that. But no, seriously on the renewal cycle, the reason you're hearing us talk about it is because we've always talked about how we
componenttext: Yes. we'll first off, thanks for the complements. I was beginning to think somebody was impersonating you. So I appreciate that. But no, seriously on the renewal cycle, the reason you're hearing us talk about it is because we've always talked about how we get into a customer. And our business grows with them, and that almost always that growth happens when we step up that renewal time. And for a long time, we were more focused on doing 1-year deals than doing multiyear deals. And so every year, each of those deals would ratchet up. Well, and I still think it's the right decision. 2.5 years ago, we decided to focus more on doing multiyear deals, so we could get the customers locked into a set of technologies on which we could then go work to upsell, which we do. But the problem with that is that's been doing that for 2.5 years, you've drained a lot of the swamp of potential renewal, which means a deal we did making it up last year that had 20% growth. well that growth roll into revenue this year is 0. And the deal we did 2 years ago that had 20-something percent growth in it is rolling through revenue flat this year. And we just don't have as many renewals, because these are the people that we couldn't get in 3-year deals in the last 2 years, that are up now. And so yes, we see good growth. And we talked about since that one competitive loss, we still see solid upsell and cross-sell in our renewals when they come up. But the renewal is typically the precipitating event to do with the upsell and cross-sell as well. Certainly, that's not always the case. We have people in multiyear deals. We have multiple other deals with them. But that renewal is that participating event. Then we just -- it's a lot lower, which if you actually ask our sales team, the amount of net new growth that they have to get this year, they're seeing growth numbers 30%, 40%, 50% depending on the region, which given I don't want to say renewals are automatic. Obviously we don't have a very high renewal rate. That amount of new business that they're seeing is like dramatically higher in terms of the new business that they have to go get and are going and getting, than you're seeing in our revenue or even our bookings numbers, because of just kind of the relatively lower renewal rate. So that's why you hear us talking about it. It's not that we're "milking" the renewal. It's just we don't have the precipitating events as often as we typically do. And again, that starts to come back next year, because we get into the steady state of -- from  3 years ago, those renewals coming back around.  I don't think there's a change in focus on what we're doing. it's just the sheer math of how much business we have that we can cross-sell and upsell on.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean John, it's Eric. In addition to what Jim said, I mean if you think about that it's, when we're out with customers, it's a national progression if they're already using RHEL, to then start to talk about using OpenShift, using OpenStack, et cete
componenttext: Yes. I mean John, it's Eric. In addition to what Jim said, I mean if you think about that it's, when we're out with customers, it's a national progression if they're already using RHEL, to then start to talk about using OpenShift, using OpenStack, et cetera. Because that technology shift makes it a whole lot easier. So as Jim said, we're not giving -- we don't want to give the impression that we have a certain set of customers that we're just relying on those renewals. we've got thousands of customers, right? And if you think about the customer engagement that we have, even looking at the CCSP program, our online program, we're harvesting those opportunities for future growth opportunities. So it starts with an our customers already using RHEL from a technology perspective, it's a whole lot easier of a conversation since they're already using our OS, to then start using OpenShift, especially as they're going to start containerizing their applications. So it really is more of a technology discussion and why it makes sense. So it's not just the fact that we're going back to the same customers, but it really is, as Jim said, a business event that makes it much easier for them to leverage newer technology.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, it's also when they want to buy. I mean, the idea of saying, "I want to buy $500,000 of OpenShift," to "What kind of discount am I going to get?" versus "I'm doing an $8 million renewal and I'm throwing this in. What kind of discount do I get?" It's
componenttext: Well, it's also when they want to buy. I mean, the idea of saying, "I want to buy $500,000 of OpenShift," to "What kind of discount am I going to get?" versus "I'm doing an $8 million renewal and I'm throwing this in. What kind of discount do I get?" It's the natural way that customers buy as well.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Jim, so it sounds like RHEL has definitely been slowing. Would you say that you've lost market share in the server operating system markets? That's one of my questions. And also maybe give us an update on CoreOS. Ansible's been a phenomenal acquisition, m
componenttext: Jim, so it sounds like RHEL has definitely been slowing. Would you say that you've lost market share in the server operating system markets? That's one of my questions. And also maybe give us an update on CoreOS. Ansible's been a phenomenal acquisition, maybe give us an update on CoreOS.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. Sure. So I certainly don't think we're losing share. If anything, we continue to gain share from our on-premise competitors. And again just looking cloud for cloud and our relative RHEL growth rates in those clouds versus their overall growth ra
componenttext: Yes, yes. Sure. So I certainly don't think we're losing share. If anything, we continue to gain share from our on-premise competitors. And again just looking cloud for cloud and our relative RHEL growth rates in those clouds versus their overall growth rates, I don't think we're losing share to whether it's Amazon Linux or any of the other Linuxes out there. So I don't see a place where we are losing share. Again, a lot of those, you're getting the math of the fact that many of our customers are in 3-year engagements that aren't growing. So you're getting this weighted average thing, and we're in the year before the renewals restart. So I don't know. I don't see us losing share at all. If anything, I see us gaining share. And again, maintaining share on public cloud as public cloud grows is also taking share. Because that's a vast majority Linux and -- versus on-premise where nearly half of the workloads are Windows. So overall, I feel very, very good about where we stand with Linux and how we're growing. What's the second part of that?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Sep 19, 2018
componenttextpreview: Oh yes, CoreOS, we're really excited about. To be clear, CoreOS is different than Ansible in the sense that Ansible was an additional product that has done extremely well for us. CoreOS is a set of features in a container platform that we are integrating
componenttext: Oh yes, CoreOS, we're really excited about. To be clear, CoreOS is different than Ansible in the sense that Ansible was an additional product that has done extremely well for us. CoreOS is a set of features in a container platform that we are integrating to OpenShift from the use perspective. We bring incredible content associated with RHEL and the RHEL ecosystem and how we life cycle. Those together, it's a phenomenal marriage. We've started to bring some of those technologies into OpenShift in the various releases. And certainly as we get into Openshift 4, you'll see kind of basically the entirety of their core feature set integrated in. And we're really excited about it. I think that's one of the reasons that we're seeing so much traction with OpenShift today.
